Welhan, Idaho Geological Survey</origin><pubdate>7-2011</pubdate><title>NEHRP Site Class and Liquefaction Susceptibility Maps for the Boise Metro Area, Idaho</title><edition>7.2011.1</edition><serinfo><sername>Digital Database</sername><issue>5</issue></serinfo><pubinfo><pubplace>Moscow, Idaho</pubplace><publish>Idaho Geological Survey</publish></pubinfo></citeinfo></lworkcit><onlink>http://www.idahogeology.org/Products/reverselook.asp?switch=title&value=NEHRP_Site_Class_and_Liquefaction_Susceptibility_Maps_for_the_Boise_Metro_Area,_Idaho</onlink></citeinfo></citation><native Sync="TRUE">Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.1 (Build 7600) ; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.0.1770</native><descript><langdata Sync="TRUE">en</langdata><abstract>This dataset provides preliminary liquefaction susceptibility maps for the metro Boise area. Liquefaction occurs during strong earthquake ground shaking when saturated, coheionsless earth materials lose strength because of high excess pore-water pressure. The database was produced using 1) a standard methodology relating deposit age, texture (grain size and sorting), and environment of deposition to liquefaction susceptibility, and, 2) depth to the local water table. The database uses 1:100,000-scale geologic map information and water well records. The water well data have uncertainities in data quality and location. For these reasons, this product is not suited for detailed engineering use. On-site geotechnical studies are required to establish actual liquefaction potential for any specific location. It is best used as a regional screening tool to focus further attention on areas with apparently high liquefaction hazards.</abstract><purpose>In order to promote mitigation of earthquake hazards, provides overview of liquefaction susceptibility for metro Boise area.</purpose><supplinf>A README file detailing methods and references is distrubuted with this database.Spreadsheets showing how individual geological units were classified are also distributed with this report.</supplinf></descript><timeperd><current>publication date</current><timeinfo><sngdate><caldate>unknown</caldate></sngdate></timeinfo></timeperd><status><progress>Complete</progress><update>As needed</update></status><spdom><bounding><westbc Sync="TRUE">-117.033495</westbc><eastbc Sync="TRUE">-115.999582</eastbc><northbc Sync="TRUE">43.881349</northbc><southbc Sync="TRUE">43.493159</southbc></bounding><lboundng><leftbc Sync="TRUE">161557.265625</leftbc><rightbc Sync="TRUE">433777.656250</rightbc><bottombc Sync="TRUE">668205.000000</bottombc><topbc Sync="TRUE">807205.062500</topbc></lboundng></spdom><keywords><theme><themekt>none</themekt><themekey>Earthquake Hazards</themekey><themekey>Liquefaction</themekey><themekey>Regional Water Table</themekey></theme><place><placekey>Boise</placekey><placekey>Meridian</placekey><placekey>Nampa</placekey><placekey>Caldwell</placekey><placekey>Ada County</placekey><placekey>Canyon County</placekey><placekey>Idaho</placekey><placekt>none</placekt><placekey>Owyhee County</placekey></place></keywords><accconst>None. (grain size and sorting), and environment of deposition (ATE). An ATE score was devised based upon a semi-quantitative ranking of ATE relevance to liquefaction.</procdesc><procsv>ESRI ArcMap version 9.3</procsv><procdate>2011</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><cntperp><cntper>William Phillips</cntper><cntorg>Idaho Geological Survey</cntorg></cntperp><cntpos>Research Geologist</cntpos><cntvoice>208-885-8928</cntvoice><cntemail>phillips@uidaho.edu</cntemail><hours>8 am - 5 pm</hours></cntinfo></proccont></procstep><procstep><procdesc>Digital geologic map downloaded from Idaho Geological Survey website and updated.</procdesc><procsv>ESRI ArcMap version 9.3</procsv><procdate>2011</procdate><proccont><cntinfo><cntperp><cntper>Loudon Stanford</cntper><cntorg>Idaho Geological Survey</cntorg></cntperp><cntvoice>208-885-7479</cntvoice><cntemail>stanford@uidaho.edu</cntemail></cntinfo></proccont></procstep><procstep><proccont><cntinfo><cntperp><cntper>John A. Welhan</cntper><cntorg>Idaho Geological Survey - Pocatello office</cntorg></cntperp><cntpos>Research Geologist</cntpos><cntvoice>208-282-4254</cntvoice><cntemail>welhjohn@isu.edu</cntemail></cntinfo></proccont><procdesc>Water table elevation below ground surface computed from water well data. Wells outside of project boundary were included to reduce edge effects. Only water wells with total depths >= 100 ft were used. Static water wells reported in wells were used as proxy for equilibirum water table elevation. Regional water table surface was constructed with Kriging tools in Geostatistical Analyst.</procdesc><procsv>ESRI ArcMap version 9.3</procsv></procstep><procstep><proccont><cntinfo><cntperp><cntper>William Phillips</cntper><cntorg>Idaho Geological Survey</cntorg></cntperp><cntpos>Research Geologist</cntpos><cntvoice>208-885-8928</cntvoice><cntemail>phillips@uidaho.edu</cntemail></cntinfo></proccont><procdesc>Water table raster surface with floating point values reclassified into integer raster with 2 gridcode values: 1 (corresponding to water table elevation <=15 ft) and 2 (corresponding to water table elevation >15 ft) with ArcMap/Spatial Analyst/Reclassify. Raster converted to polygons with ArcMap/Spatial Analyst/Convert/Raster to Features. Polygons smoothed (because of irregular stair-steps) with ArcMap/Spatial Analyst/Data Management/Generalize/Smooth Polygons/PAEK/Tolerance = 6000.</procdesc><procsv>ESCRI ArcMap version 9.3</procsv></procstep><procstep><proccont><cntinfo><cntperp><cntper>William M Phillips</cntper><cntorg>Idaho Geological Survey</cntorg></cntperp><cntpos>Research Geologist</cntpos><cntvoice>208-885-8928</cntvoice><cntemail>phillips@uidaho.edu</cntemail></cntinfo></proccont><procdesc>ATE_score and LC_class fields added to geological map shapefile. Geological map shapefile and water table elevation shapefile INTERSECTED. LC field computed with Field Calculator using  Visual Basic Statements. IF ATE_score>12 AND gridcode=1 Then LQ_class = 5 ElseIf ATE_score = 12 AND gridcode = 1 Then LQ_class = 4 ElseIf gridcode = 1 And (ATE_score<12 And ATE_score >0 ) Then LQ_class=3 ElseIf gridcode=2 And ATE_score>11 Then LQ_class=3 ElseIf gridecode=2 And ATE_score>11 Then LQ_class=2 ElseIF gridcode=2 And ATE_score>0 then LQ_class=1  The LC_class is liquefaction susceptibility as defined in the README file distributed with this product.</procdesc><procsv>ESCRI ArcMap version 9.3</procsv><procdate>2011</procdate></procstep><procstep><proccont><cntinfo><cntperp><cntper>Loudon Stanford</cntper><cntorg>Idaho Geological Survey</cntorg></cntperp><cntvoice>208-885-7479</cntvoice><cntemail>stanford@uidaho.edu</cntemail></cntinfo></proccont><procdesc>LC_class plotted on Boise project area basemap and prepared for distribution</procdesc><procsv>ESCRI ArcMap version 9.3</procsv><procdate>2011</procdate></procstep></lineage><attracc><attraccr>Liquefaction susceptibility for any specific polygon is not established by this report. It must be verified by site-specific investigation. This is because input geological data was at at scale of 1:100,000. This creates uncertainties about the boundaries of polygons that have been assigned a specific age-texture-environment. Also, water wells with accuracy as poor as 1/4 of 1/4 of a public land system section (about 40 acres) are used. This causes uncertainties in the location of high water tables.</attraccr></attracc><logic>Assignments of liquefaciton susceptibility class spot checked against input data of age-texture-environment scores and water table depth below ground surface. High water table areas supported by only one water well were deleted.</logic><complete>All polygons have an assigned liquefaction class. </complete><posacc><horizpa><horizpar>Location of polygons based in part on 1:100,000-scale geologic map and water wells with locations as poor as 40 acres.</horizpar></horizpa></posacc></dataqual><spdoinfo><direct Sync="TRUE">LQ_class</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">Number</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">9</attwidth><attrdomv><edom><edomv>0</edomv><edomvd>Underlain by bedrock. Liquefaction will not occur even where saturated except in the case of undocumented cohesionless materials.</edomvd></edom><edom><edomv>1</edomv><edomvd>Not subject to saturation under ordinary conditions. Underlain by materials that generally do not contain cohesionless sediments. Liquefaction not expected.</edomvd></edom><edom><edomv>2</edomv><edomvd>Not subject to saturation under ordinary conditions. Underlain by materials that may contain cohesionless sediments. Liquefaction not expected except in exceptional circumstances where saturation occurs.</edomvd></edom><edom><edomv>3</edomv><edomvd>Subject to at least annual saturation. Underlain by materials that generally do not contain cohesionless sediments. </edomvd></edom><edom><edomv>4</edomv><edomvd>Subject to at least annual saturation. Underlain by late Pleistocene Bonneville flood deposits that may contain cohesionless sediments in some areas. </edomvd></edom><edom><edomv>5</edomv><edomvd>Subject to at least annual saturation. Underlain by Holocene alluvium that likely contains some cohesionless sediments.</edomvd></edom></attrdomv><attrdef>Liquefaction_code</attrdef><attrdefs>Idaho Geological Survey</attrdefs></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">FID_Boise_</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">FID_Boise_</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">Number</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">9</attwidth></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">MAPUNIT_</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">MAPUNIT_</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">Number</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">9</attwidth></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">MAPUNIT_ID</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">MAPUNIT_ID</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">Number</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">9</attwidth></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">AREA</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">AREA</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">Float</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">13</attwidth><atnumdec Sync="TRUE">11</atnumdec></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">PERIMETER</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">PERIMETER</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">Float</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">13</attwidth><atnumdec Sync="TRUE">11</atnumdec></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">VALUE</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">VALUE</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">String</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">10</attwidth></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">ATE_score</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">ATE_score</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">Number</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">9</attwidth></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">LQ_class_1</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">LQ_class_1</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">Number</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">9</attwidth></attr><attr><attrlabl Sync="TRUE">Boundary</attrlabl><attalias Sync="TRUE">Boundary</attalias><attrtype Sync="TRUE">String</attrtype><attwidth Sync="TRUE">50</attwidth></attr></detailed><overview><dsoverv>This dataset provides preliminary liquefaction susceptibility maps for the metro Boise area. Liquefaction occurs during strong earthquake ground shaking when saturated, coheionsless earth materials lose strength because of high excess pore-water pressure. The database was produced using 1) a standard methodology relating deposit age, texture (grain size and sorting), and environment of deposition to liquefaction susceptibility, and, 2) depth to the local water table. The database uses 1:100,000-scale geologic map information and water well records. The water well data have uncertainities in data quality and location. For these reasons, this product is not suited for detailed engineering use. On-site geotechnical studies are required to establish actual liquefaction potential for any specific location. It is best used as a regional screening tool to focus further attention on areas with apparently high liquefaction hazards.</dsoverv><eaover>EXPLANATION OF LIQUEFACTION SUSCEPTIBILITY CLASSES  Class 5: Subject to at least annual saturation. Underlain by Holocene alluvium that likely contains some cohesionless sediments.  Class 4: Subject to at least annual saturation. Underlain by late Pleistocene Bonneville flood deposits that may contain cohesionless sediments in some areas.   Class 3: Subject to at least annual saturation. Underlain by materials that generally do not contain cohesionless sediments.   Class 2: Not subject to saturation under ordinary conditions. Underlain by materials that may contain cohesionless sediments. Liquefaction not expected except in exceptional circumstances where saturation occurs.  Class 1: Not subject to saturation under ordinary conditions. Underlain by materials that generally do not contain cohesionless sediments. Liquefaction not expected.  Class 0: Underlain by bedrock. Liquefaction will not occur even where saturated except in the case of undocumented cohesionless materials.  Processing Steps:  1) water well data downloaded from Idaho Department of Water Resources and edited for locational accuracy and missing data.  2) Each geologic unit classified on the basis of age, texture (grain size and sorting), and environment of deposition (ATE). An ATE score was devised based upon a semi-quantitative ranking of ATE relevance to liquefaction.  3) Digital geologic map downloaded from Idaho Geological Survey website and updated.  4) Water table elevation below ground surface computed from water well data. Wells outside of project boundary were included to reduce edge effects. Only water wells with total depths >= 100 ft were used. Static water wells reported in wells were used as proxy for equilibirum water table elevation. Regional water table surface was constructed with Kriging tools in Geostatistical Analyst.  5) Water table raster surface with floating point values reclassified into integer raster with 2 gridcode values: 1 (corresponding to water table elevation <=15 ft) and 2 (corresponding to water table elevation >15 ft) with ArcMap/Spatial Analyst/Reclassify. Raster converted to polygons with ArcMap/Spatial Analyst/Convert/Raster to Features. Polygons smoothed (because of irregular stair-steps) with ArcMap/Spatial Analyst/Data Management/Generalize/Smooth Polygons/PAEK/Tolerance = 6000.  6) ATE_score and LC_class fields added to geological map shapefile. Geological map shapefile and water table elevation shapefile INTERSECTED. LC field computed with Field Calculator using  Visual Basic Statements. IF ATE_score>12 AND gridcode=1 Then LQ_class = 5 ElseIf ATE_score = 12 AND gridcode = 1 Then LQ_class = 4 ElseIf gridcode = 1 And (ATE_score<12 And ATE_score >0 ) Then LQ_class=3 ElseIf gridcode=2 And ATE_score>11 Then LQ_class=3 ElseIf gridecode=2 And ATE_score>11 Then LQ_class=2 ElseIF gridcode=2 And ATE_score>0 then LQ_class=1  The LC_class is liquefaction susceptibility as defined in the README file distributed with this product.</eaover></overview></eainfo><metainfo><langmeta Sync="TRUE">en</langmeta><metstdn Sync="TRUE">FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata</metstdn><metstdv Sync="TRUE">FGDC-STD-001-1998</metstdv><mettc Sync="TRUE">local time</mettc><metc><cntinfo><cntorgp><cntper>Loudon R.
